Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Pilot Studies for Representing and Archiving Integrative Structural Models of Macromolecular Machines and Supporting Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
New techniques have emerged that allow the determination of the three dimensional structures of very large macromolecular assemblies. These larger biological systems play key roles in basic molecular biology, photosynthesis, nanotechnology, and health. Rather than relying on a single technique, the three dimensional structures of these molecular machines are being determined by integrating results from many different kinds of experiments using computational methods. In order to allow these integrative, or hybrid, models to enable future research by the broad community of scientists and also provide for the development of new educational platforms, it is essential to develop a way to archive these data and make them easily accessible.

Several steps are necessary to achieve this goal. Current archiving of macromolecular structures depends on the fixed spatial positions of atoms; therefore the existing representation of these models must be extended to include both non-atomistic and spatio-temporal models. A new infrastructure will be developed that allows for the federation of different experimental repositories hosting data sets contributing to these integrative models. Once this infrastructure is developed, it will be necessary to prototype a system for depositing and archiving these new integrative models and supporting data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent investigations in the field of structural and molecular biology have led to the development of novel integrative/hybrid (I/H) modeling methods that incorporate spatial information derived from a variety of experimental and computational techniques along with data derived from physics and statistics to elucidate the structures of complex macromolecular assemblies. While these modeling methods bring about the structural characterization of biomolecular complexes using time-intensive algorithms, there are no standard mechanisms to represent and archive the results of these investigations so that they are available to the community at large. The major goals of this project include creation of a data representation to capture the details of integrative modeling and use this as a foundation to build a prototype system for deposition and archiving of I/H models. This project addresses a timely need in the evolving field of structural biology and advances the “FAIR” guiding principles of making the results of integrative modeling “Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable”.

The significant outcomes of this research project are:

  1. A set of data specifications that describe the results of integrative modeling. These data specifications address the important features of I/H modeling including representations of I/H models in multiple spatiotemporal scales and conformational states and definitions of spatial information derived from a variety of experimental and computational techniques. These data specifications are captured in a software-amenable “dictionary” of data terms and collectively form the set of data standards required for archiving I/H models. This data dictionary and supporting documentation are available at https://github.com/ihmwg/IHM-dictionary.
  2. A prototype system for deposition and archiving of I/H models. This system has been built using software tools that adhere to current industry standards and facilitates seamless exchange of data among a network of resources that contribute to structural biology. Three example I/H models spanning a variety of features of integrative modeling have been deposited and archived in the prototype system. These models are freely available for download in a format compliant with the newly developed data specifications and can be visualized using structural biology visualization software. The prototype system and the archived I/H models are available at https://pdb-dev.wwpdb.org and the software to visualize these structures can be downloaded from https://www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimerax/.

This project has enabled the creation of a data pipeline for deposition, archiving, dissemination and visualization of I/H models. It is important to recognize that before the initiation of this project, no mechanisms were available to archive any of these results. The outcomes of this project ensure that the results of I/H investigations are archived appropriately and made available to the scientific community and the general public for utilization towards the advancement of worldwide education, healthcare and research.

The underlying broader impact of this project is the promulgation of data standards in every aspect of the structural biology pipeline and the demonstrated value of using community consensus to ensure their implementation. In addition, the provision of a Structural View of Biology for specialists and the broader scientific and lay communities allows a growing user community to study and understand molecular function at the structural level, in areas ranging from health and disease to cell and molecular biology to nanotechnology and biomolecular design.
